title: "Owner" marker to lower-right corner of cache icon
body:
### Tell us your idea!

On the map there are additional visual markers added to cache icons to indicate various information. 
- found / DNF / offline logs are placed in upper-left
- stored is placed in upper-right
- list color is placed in mid-left
- personal note is placed lower-left
- owner marker is placed in upper-left, obscuring any log marker. 

For cache owners who saved offline logs this is an issue, because there is no visual cue to show those logs exist.

### What solution would you suggest?

Move the "owner" marker to lower-right, so far apparently unused, or at least with all the combinations that I have with caches I haven't seen it used.

![Screenshot_20241027-104713_cgeo owner marker (2)](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/359971d3-b83e-420f-a3f7-16032031a3ec)


If it is used, then a solution should be found to illustrate both "owner" and logs, especially offline logs. 

### Is there an alternative?

None at the moment. (2024.10.14)

### Additional Information

_No response_

title: Wherigo Player: The possibility to select what to delete
body:
### Tell us your idea!

At the moment, in Wherigo Player, when you select the delete button, there is only the option to delete the cartridge (the cartridge name does not appear) along with the existing savegames.

It would be good to have the option to choose what to delete: everything, only the savegames, or a specific savegame.



### What solution would you suggest?

If feasible, an example would be to use checkboxes to select what should be deleted.

If I recall correctly the autosave always replace the previous autosave with the new one, so it would be 1 check box to the autosave if present + 4 checkboxes for the saves if they exist, 1 for the cartridge, and 1 for all.

title: Stored Lists: tapping on list selection opens list selection on top (not where the currently selected list is located)
body:
Request from a [Support Ticket #324796](https://cgeosupport.droescher.eu/scp/tickets.php?id=8313)
c:geo version 2024.07.26-RC

A user on support asks for the new list selection dialog for Stored lists (opened when tapping on currently shown list in header) opens already scrolled to the list currently selected in "Stored List" Activity. Currently, it always opens at the top of the list - which requires lots of scrolling if one just wants to move to the "next list".

Example: in the following screenshot, a list with name "white" is opened. When user taps on this list name, the list selection dialog opens, but the list "white" is not visible (one needs to scroll down to see it).

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/ace2e77e-7718-4bcf-bc7b-c7c531722635)
 

Original request:

I use Lists a lot in c:geo and have created a lot of Lists.
When being in a List of Caches, and want to navigate to another List, I click on the downward pointing arrow at the top, next to the List name.

Before the latest Release, that would have opened a drop-down-list of all Lists.
Which is indeed the expected behavior of clicking on such a downward pointing arrow.
More, that drop-down-list of all Lists opened positioned at the level of the current List.
That made navigation to adjacent Lists very easy.
Also, the width of the drop-down-list was automatically resized to the length of the lists names, if needed to the full screen width. 
Perfect !

Since the latest Release, clicking on the downward pointing arrow at the top now opens a 'Pick a list' window.
That window always opens at the top of the list of Lists, instead of at the level of the current List.
To navigate to a List adjacent to the one I am in, I have to scroll down the full list.
Clumsy.
Also, the width of that object is not resized.


It seems that in the current Release, the list of List used when being in a List, has the same behavior now as the List of lists used when being in a Cache and storing it in Lists.
It shouldn't, as these two usecases are very different.


I  would like to ask to go back to the previous drop-down-list of all Lists.

If this is not possible, I  would like to ask to open the 'Pick a list' window positioned at the level of the current List.

title: Cache Logging: default action for trackables in inventory is updated on "log send" only - should be done on "log save"
body:
### Tell us your idea!

While working on support ticket 841995 I noticed a potentially confusing behavior of c:geo.

When logging a gc.com cache, c:geo offers to send actions for trackables in inventory (one of do nothing, visited or dropped off):
![image](https://github.com/cgeo/cgeo/assets/6909759/40eed246-ef6d-486c-a0d1-a9250c5d74c9)

Users often have different "default actions" they want to have associated with trackables in their inventory. For example, some should log a "visited" on every found cache, others should maybe not get logged ("do nothing"). To ease log creation, c:geo stores the last used action on a per-trackable-basis and pre-fills log screen with this action.

c:geo stores a new "default action" on a trackable every time a log is sent to gc.com server (not when it is just saved locally offline). This can lead to following confusing scenario:

* User creates a log, He changes the default-action-to-far "visible" to "do nothing" for an inventory tb while do so. He saves the log (not sending it)
* User creates a new log for another cache. --> now in this log the default action is again filled with "visible" (because previous log was not yet send). This is potentially confusing


### What solution would you suggest?

Update inventory-tb-default-action on log-save (not on log-send)

### Is there an alternative?

do nothing

### Additional Information

I want to put this up for discussion

title: Restoring newer backup not possible
body:
Today I needed to test something against `release` branch while emulator was set up with a build from `master`.
`release` is on db version 100, `master` on 101 (in my local setting).

I installed the compiled version and landed in configuration wizard (probably due to different app id), so I chose "restore database" to import my existing data. That failed with the following error:

![image](https://github.com/cgeo/cgeo/assets/3754370/ce4c8c5c-2bf0-4dc2-99ef-a109535e6f37)

If technically possible this situation should also be handled by our "is version of database compatible to version expected by build" check.

Might be related to #15031/#15036.

title: Elevation chart for route / individual route
body:
### Tell us your idea!

It would be nice to see the change of elevation along a route, be it a route to currently selected target or an individual route.

### What solution would you suggest?

Add an option to display such a chart, vertical axis would be elevation, horizontal axis distance, with left-most point start point of route, right-most point end point of route.

Example:
![image](https://www.topo-gps.com/android/en/manual/html/_images/route-profile3.png)
_(Source: https://www.topo-gps.com)_

Displaying this info should be on-demand, not permanent.
This could be either a split view as shown above or a separate view.
(If we go for a split view we could use a draggable marker on the elevation chart to highlight the corresponding point on the map.)

### Is there an alternative?

don't add such a function

### Additional Information

BRouter already gives us elevation info together with routing data, we just don't store it yet.

title: Elevation info needs a better icon
body:
### Describe your problem!

I talked to some beta users and even myself was fooled by the elevation info on the map.
As it shows "a ramp" users might first thing, that it shows an elevation difference (e.g. if a route is active in parallel).
This is emphasized by the fact, that its shown in the same screen area, which normally only shows distances to target, routing length, etc.

At least we should IMHO try to find a better icon, ideally we could also find a better place to show that info on the map screen (e.g. upper left instead upper right) to visualize its not related to routing and distance information.

title: Routing profiles: Add "Boat" resp. "Canoe" and "MTB"
body:
### Tell us your idea!

In [BRouter's routing profile downloads](https://brouter.de/brouter/profiles2/) I just stumbled upon "river.brf" - and was immediately caught by the arousing possibilities, because that's exactly what we've always missed when going for boat caches so far.

BTW: Perhaps [Canua](https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.touchingcode.canua&hl=en&gl=US) may be added to [c:geo's useful apps section](https://manual.cgeo.org/en/mainmenu/utilityprograms) cause even in the free version it's extremely helpful for planning boat caches.

However: Some "dry" couch tests showed good results - thus it would be great to have a corresponding button in the map quick settings (and of course profile settings, to choose which profile to use - default should be "river.brf", of course).

And perhaps a second choice for biking may be implemented in the same go, as we often switch between road bike (for commuting) and MTB (mtb.brf - for the fun) - but being forced to always change the profile via the route settings is a bit annoying. 

Icons could be like e. g. in [Komoot](https://www.komoot.de/plan/@49.0000000,9.2149000,9.000z?sport=mtb&constitution=4) resp. a minimalistic canoe like [this one](https://www.flaticon.com/de/kostenloses-icon/ruderboot_3124366) on flaticon.com.


![Routing Icons](https://github.com/cgeo/cgeo/assets/9889015/0588f2f1-5787-4707-948b-556fd5199b71) ![Boat](https://github.com/cgeo/cgeo/assets/9889015/8e7d0ab7-044a-4f4b-a427-7c0a1d0984e3)






### What solution would you suggest?

Additional routing profile choices for "Boat" resp. "Canoe" and "MTB".

### Is there an alternative?

Switching profiles in routing settings.

_No response_

title: UI efficiency improvement - edit log image
body:
### Tell us your idea!

Currently the UI for adding a log image is reasonable, with the necessary fields and works ok. 

Logging multiple finds and adding images to each of them I discovered the UI makes it somewhat cumbersome. 
My use case was simple: load an already existing image (photos taken earlier), add a caption, end.
The UI requires me to either scroll or close the keyboard to finalize this form, because the "OK" button is hidden by the keyboard. 

Keyboard open, covering "OK" button.
![Screenshot_20230814-160705_cgeo](https://github.com/cgeo/cgeo/assets/3382777/339ba99d-b473-43ab-9fff-dbea7cff5b39)

Keyboard closed, "OK" button visible.
![Screenshot_20230814-160711_cgeo](https://github.com/cgeo/cgeo/assets/3382777/0e777004-a774-4b5e-aca6-13dd136e2c95)



### What solution would you suggest?

Since the most often use case is only edit the caption, it would be more efficient to have access to the "OK" button above the area of the screen where the soft keyboard appears. 

My suggestion would be above the "existing" and "new" buttons, with the logic that most action buttons in c:geo are on the top part of the screen.



### Is there an alternative?

_No response_

### Additional Information


User desiring to edit description still has scroll or "next" button on keyboard.
User desiring to change image size still has scroll. 
But these controls I believe are much less often accessed.

title: Don't show the same image twice in gallery
body: We shouldn't show the same image twice in the gallery, if the large and small version of the same GC image upload are used in the listing. Background: --- **Analysis** I used https://coord.info/GC1HEBH. This is a typical side using attachment images which are also displayed in the listing. E.g. the image "Fischerprüfung" is also shown in the listing: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6909759/168005616-7c42bcbe-d68c-4e6d-ad73-a28ae07290b2.png) ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6909759/168005708-6635b9cc-aea5-4d19-a668-967093076786.png) In HTML source the two URLs used are only slightly different (attachment references "large" version of image, embedded image does not): * Image embedded in listing: `` * Image as attachment: `Fischerprüfung` In c:geo image gallery the image is displayed two times: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6909759/168006507-9d766572-531b-4e3d-a7e3-4e970aa3e6b7.png) As of today, the GCConnector does not differentiate between the two, both are delivered as images to c:geo core. THe information whether the image is an attachment or from listing is not passed. **Solution possibilities** What we could do: * We could introduce a new image category LISTING_ATTACHMENT and make the connector(s) differentiate between the two * For spoiler view we could filter out displayed images by ignoring the "large" in URL comparison * We could in general (not only for spoiler images) filter out duplicate images in image gallery this way... _Originally posted by @eddiemuc in https://github.com/cgeo/cgeo/issues/12938#issuecomment-1124582668_

title: Introduce Resize Factors for map font/lines/symbols
body:
### Tell us your idea!

In OSM map elements, esp. text is quite hard to read (i. e. really small) on high resolution displays, esp. if you use Elevate5 as map theme.  Therefore, I have written a script which increases fonts, lines and symbols by a configurable factor, which massively increases usability.

The other day I learned two things:
1. I am not the only one with this "problem". 
2. Locus has a setting for this, in fact, to increase all map elements by a configurable factor ...

... what gave me the idea that c:geo could perhaps offer this functionality, too.  ;)

### What solution would you suggest?

From my experience, it turned out to be best to have three factors:

1. Font Size
2. Line Width
3. Symbol Size

... as in fact I like the theme best, if fonts are increased to 160, lines to 120 and symbols to 130 percent,
while my teammate prefers F140/L120/S110 and a friend of ours even wanted to have F180/L120/S130.
Although my script can create all three in one go, life would be way easier, if c:geo would support to do this itself.  ;)

### Is there an alternative?

Just write yourself a script to increase sizes ...  ;)

### Additional Information

As an example here a comparison between original (in fact close to unreadable) vs. "my" F160, L120 S130:

![Current](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9889015/166129743-99b5491b-2d88-42ca-9475-952389318942.jpg) ![Font 160 Lines 120 Symbols 130](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9889015/166129750-7206c548-d96b-436b-b068-17b710c58b58.jpg)

title: Show location accuracy in "add waypoint" dialog
body:
### Tell us your idea!

In "Add waypoint" dialog there's a button to insert "my location" which uses Location Provider to get the device location.
Due to the nature of Location Provider this info will be more or less accurate, e.g. before opening the dialog only coarse location is used, then when opening it it switches to precise location but that takes some time to get a lock. So opening the dialog and repeatedly pressing the button will give you different results - usually getting more precise.

Most users will not be aware of this fact and just open the dialog, click on "my location" and exit it again, resulting in an inaccurate location.

To raise awareness of the quality/reliability of this information we should display the accuracy somewhere in the dialog. This would enable users to wait until they get a lock that's "good enough" for them.


### What solution would you suggest?

Add the location accuracy to the "my location" button and update it regulary (ideally event-based if Location Provider has that ability, otherwise time-based). We can probably check the map accuracy circle for the best way of doing that.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1258173/165147488-06179e37-d0f1-40b0-b485-a433a72f278b.png)


### Is there an alternative?

_No response_

### Additional Information

_No response_

title: Live map: replace skeuomorphic location indicator
body:
### Tell us your idea!

I've been away from geocaching for a while, and was (happily) surprised to see a new material-design-esque UI. A couple of things stood out as a bit jarring though: mostly the glowing location indicator. 

![2022-03-24-010700](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/35242550/159870505-a23f9949-7e0d-4d62-8c44-5cf304962b77.png) (c:geo's location icon)

It's a very skeuomorphic design and reminds me strongly of Google Maps on the iPhone 3. Not that that's bad on its own! I sometimes miss the old gem-like interfaces that used to be everywhere. But it doesn't fit very well with the rest of the app being material design.

![2022-03-24-011446](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/35242550/159871858-c8560aef-e0a6-42e0-ad01-eee24e133b8d.png) (location indicator on the iPhone 3)

I also think the quick settings menu could possibly be moved up to the top bar (plus, it has a lot of overlapping functionality with the filter menu), and the zoom in / out buttons might look better round, but those are probably separate issues.


### What solution would you suggest?

Something flatter and less glowey would fit better. 

This is what Google Maps currently uses: 
![2022-03-24-011749](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/35242550/159872485-a9dad6b4-4528-4f8f-ac6d-acac46e69ed7.png)

I think that knowing the precise location you're pointing is important enough when geocaching that the location indicator should still be an arrow for clarity.

Something like this might work well: 
![2022-03-24-012031](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/35242550/159872822-c910ee43-5413-41fd-9f36-1504c2ef512f.png) 
![2022-03-24-012112](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/35242550/159873219-5bc68de2-43c7-4f11-8153-b1d13e1f6bf9.png)

Or keeping the original arrow shape: 
![2022-03-24-012423](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/35242550/159873493-ef18ed7f-93ae-4d4a-9130-649fa658742c.png)



### Is there an alternative?

_No response_

### Additional Information

_No response_

title: Allow upload of own spoiler images
body:
### Tell us your idea!

I was recently approached by a geocacher who would like to have the possibility to add own, private images to a geocache (e.g. spoiler images and such) which should be kept on the cache but of course not be made public (e.g. via log).

When I heard this I thought about the existing c:geo feature to upload spoiler images in the already existing folder `GeocachePhotos`.  With this in mind it would be very easy to allow the user from within c:geo to add and remove own images to this structure.



### What solution would you suggest?

* Add the well-known "add image from gallery" / "add image from camera" to the top of the image list of a cache to select new images to add
* Mark own "spoiler images" somehow (e.g. by adding "Own image" to the title) since with this feature their usage may become more common
* Put a delete button next to the own images for deletion

The following is a crudely MS-painted screenshot on how this could look like (the upper image is supposed to be an image from the cache, the lower one an own image)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6909759/154841051-8b80d532-4140-4f24-97b4-9faf72306dda.png)




### Is there an alternative?

No implementation

title: Improve formula parsing
body:
IMHO the current syntax is not 100% intuitive. The situation will become much better, we are more tolerant about using different special characters with the same meaning. E.g.:

|||
-|-
![Screenshot_20211225_021437_cgeo geocaching](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/64581222/147392390-e62d30a8-8e57-4486-bf21-5733baf47382.png)|![Screenshot_20211225_005048_cgeo geocaching](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/64581222/147392391-376e9f0c-3918-4e35-a50c-58c1b2bb058f.png)

Furthermore, the multi-char-variables parsing could be improved. If the first character is not defined as variable, take the next characters until the name it is known as valid variable. 

And last but not least: Do variable names really need to be case sensitive? 

![Screenshot_20211225_022144_cgeo geocaching](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/64581222/147392392-d0e76f9c-0cb6-4975-91fb-146ff855fb9a.png)

title: quick-load geocode from clipboard text
body:
### Tell us your idea!

I often get messages like "I'm at cache GCxxxxxx, do you have a hint?" upon which I look up my cache notes in cgeo. The required steps to do that are:
1. Copy message
2. Paste message somewhere so i can select only the GC code (depends on the messenger)
3. In cgeo.main screen click search
4. Long-click the search field -> paste
5. On keyboard click the search icon

It'd be nice to have a more convenient way to load a cache whichs code is in clipboard.

### What solution would you suggest?

Next to the search field/in main menu add a "load from clipboard" action that takes the current clipboard and, of it's more than just a geocode, extracts a geocode from it, then loads that cache. This would be similar to the existing "from clipboard" function in defining a waypoint.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1258173/143659340-e6feb504-5160-4f43-8f6a-2cc9d297832c.png)


### Is there an alternative?

_No response_

### Additional Information

Geocode recognition should look at the enabled connectors to see what a geocode could look like to avoid false recognitions. E.g. with only gc connector enabled OC123 shouldn't be recognized as geocode.

title: Bottom navigation: How to structure the "more" page?
body:
### Tell us your idea!

Although I really like the new bottom navigation look in general, I'm still somewhat unsatisfied with the look of the "more" page. Currently it's more or less an unsorted bunch of links (no offense intended! I do know where all those links come from...). For a basic member, it looks like this:
![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3754370/137530656-aeebe4f3-85d7-41c8-b780-437a1a9ac4c9.png)

And a gc.com PM even has two more entries (bookmarks / pocket queries). Depending on screen length and font sizes, you'll even have to scroll...

I have no ready-at-hand idea how to do this, so I'd like to start a gathering of ideas how to enhance and structure this page.

### What solution would you suggest?

A starting point could be to transfer two or three easily recognizable and frequently used links to icons in the toolbar, e. g.
- Settings
- About c:geo

This should be easy to realize and cause no harm, but will reduce the list by two entries already.
(If we agree on implementing #11897, this would be the third icon on this toolbar.)

Next I thought of some grouping of the remaining ten entries, but alas they are nearly as much diverse as possible :-) - Have not found a helpful grouping for the entries yet.

Another idea could be to change the textual entries into a two-column layout of large graphical buttons (+ text), but this would solve neither the grouping problem nor the possibility of having to scroll.

Any ideas whether we can leave-out some of those entries? 
We had some discussion about the "scan geocode" feature lately, but haven't decide to remove it for now. 
"Useful apps" could become a separate tab on the "about c:geo" screen (as we have other useful links regarding c:geo over there already), which would simply transfer the problem to a different, but less-crowded, place.

Also we should discuss the order in which the entries are shown. IMHO the most important entries should stay at the top (as they mostly do, currently only "report problem" seems to me being too important for staying at the end of the list).

### Is there an alternative?

hopefully plenty :-)

### Additional Information

_No response_

title: Improve variables creation workflow
body:
rel. to #11520



Currently, it requires 5 clicks (IMHO _way_ too much) to create a new variable. I have multiple ideas how to improve this workflow:

- [ ] Make keyboard popping up automatically (for all text input dialogs in cgeo)
- [ ] Instead of allowing "can be left empty" for variable names, add a dedicated top-level button for it
- [ ] Remove "A-E" button, as it IMHO has no benefit. No one will ever need exactly 5 variables. (Without being a gamer, I have a click speed of ~6 clicks per second, so the suggested top-level button should do the same job. Simply click it 5x, which still takes less time than opening the "create variable"-dialog once.)
- [ ] Automatically focus the value field and open keyboard after a variable is created

---
Just for reference - These are the steps which are required to create a new waypoint currently:

1. Press "+" button
![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/64581222/136570480-55cbadf3-0004-43a6-8f4d-7ede09b47240.png)



2. Make keyboard popping up

![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/64581222/136570603-4d832513-3a30-4fe1-bb3f-9a03f2434fd4.png)

![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/64581222/136570680-aca91516-85ac-45be-beab-f468b062e5d2.png)

![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/64581222/136570729-66a4c2ad-1e92-4b7d-b670-eec1bb0dcf81.png)

title: Show the last few logs in map popup
body:
### Tell us your idea!

When clicking a cache on the map the popup with summary information appears. This popup should get a new line showing icons for the latest logs available.
This would allow to get a quick glance at the "health" of the cache.

Similar features are implemented by GC little helper and Locus

Screenshot from GClh
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1258173/132956364-a1b22e93-45b8-495e-a548-65300b9173cf.png)


### Usecase

As a cacher out in the field I select the next cache I plan to visit and want to see important information at a glance that will help me find the cache.
This includes D/T rating, size - and whether the cache was last found or not. If there's many DNFs I might not want to search for too long compared to a cache with recent founds. 

Potential problems:
- Information is outdated and thus the wrong conclusion is made - That however holds true for a lot of info when offline caching, the cache could be archived, moved, ... - Mitigation: Make it visible how old the information shown is.
- No logs available -> Don't show the section at all.

### Additional Information

Of course this can only use the latest information available, like for an offline cache this info might be outdated, but that's true for all the information, so not really an advantage.

You can assign this to me, I can take a look at this after vectorIcons is done.

title: Extend support for calculated variables in cache
body:
Last days I thought about how we can add better support for calculated values into c:geo especially for mysteries and multis. We already have the waypoint calculator but it has a few drawbacks:
* it can only calculate waypoints from variables. However I often have to calculate other things as well esp numbers to open locks, checksums and such
* It does not allow for usage of e.g. formulas. For example I often need to calculate Buchstabenwortwerte (what's the English word for it?) or checksums and have to leave c:geo for it
* It is somewhat deeply buried into the waypoint details which makes it difficult to use.

Therefore I propose the introduction of a new cache tab "Variables" which allows for adding variables and put a formula on them. Here's a sketch on how this may look:

![IMG_20210823_133035__01.jpg](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6909759/130441186-ff781d32-f046-48ba-88f3-f881a6663876.jpg)

Additional ideas:
* Variables created here could be used in waypoint calculator of course
* A scan could be implemented trying to parse formulas/variables from listing and adding them here. Might be a heuristic approach where user can decide whether a result is correct or not before it is added. (A 100% correct scan is probably impossible to implement)
* Functions available for usage in formulas must be discussed. Whatever set is chosen it can easily be extended later.

Idea is also to make the entries editable directly (no "open" step necessary) to ease their usage in the field.

Some more details, probably not so important right now:
* No strong typing of variables. Current idea is to support text and int as values in the variables. If something looks like an int it is interpreted as such, otherwise as text. Is float support necessary?
* Variable names are Case-sensitive and start with a letter. Can be composed of letters and digits otherwise
* In a formula, every letter-block is interpreted as a constant text, except if a variable of same name exists (then it is interpreted as the variable of course). Optionally text can be enclosed by " or '

What do you think?

title: Add nested filters
body:
What about opening a sub-filter screen, to allow building of nested filters via UI?

![Screenshot_20210719_225138_copy_540x671](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/64581222/126225866-101d7632-9bb5-41f2-aae9-409498349444.jpg)

I guess this would be the cleanest and feature richest solution, where most code parts AFAIK even could be reused without much effort.

title: New Filter Framework: remove "Found by" search?
body:
While working on new filter framework I discovered a potential problem:

c:geo offers currently a lot of "Search by" functions in the search activity. Those were clearly originally copied from the old/legacy gc.com-search here: https://www.geocaching.com/seek/nearest.aspx

Among them is the search function "Found by" (Gefunden von):

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6909759/124426473-5fe44780-dd6a-11eb-9ed0-834c60f510fd.png)

Now the problem: 
* this kind of search is not supported by the new filter framework for geocaching.com
* It **can't** be supported by the new framework because the web proxy search interface used does not offer the possibility to search by "Found by" (it supports only search by "not found by")

Since gc.com is our "major service" I see two possible solutions out of this
* Remove "Found by" search function from c:geo. As said before this was clearly only introduced anyway because it was once available on (now legacy) gc.com search, and it is no longer available to the users via "normal" website
* Leave legacy search for this specific function. However, new filter framework can NOT be used in interconnection

I am strongly suggest the first solution (remove search function). What is your opinion?

title: Optimize "icon buttons"
body:
## What function are you missing
While our new icon buttons looks fine in general, there are still two caveats (IMHO):
- they use more space than the old ones, although the old ones were already relatively large and easy to use (touch target)
- the image itself ("the inner part") is much smaller than with the old buttons, so they are harder to recognize, and there's much unused white space around it

This leads to a third thing, very visible in our cache popup:
The "more details" button does not have a fixed height identical to the icon buttons any longer, which makes this button way smaller, which leads to a strange look of both types are close by. The old look, having same height, was a very straight-forward, clean look, visually stable. But giving the "more details" button the same height as our new icon buttons makes it clumsy and way too big.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3754370/124348914-f7239080-dbec-11eb-9788-92c31f66bc1f.png)
(to the left: new style and two "old" buttons for comparison / to the right: old style)

## Suggested solution
- decrease the icon button size to the same dimensions as the old icon buttons had
- increase the size of the "inner image" to mostly fill the (decreased) dimensions
- adjust "more details" (and any other default button) to have (at least) the same height as the icon buttons

## Alternatives/workarounds
- make "more details" button full width
- find a different placement for the "hint" icon button, maybe by placing "refresh" and "delete" on the same line, and placing "edit list" and "hint" on the second

But that would solve only the third issue.

title: Optimize popup title bar
body:
IMHO our map popup needs at least still dome finetuning.
In general the redesign is OK (except if we want to replace it by some other material design element e.g. a bottom sheet) but looking at this example we should at least thing about the title bar:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/949669/123547106-b8f71e80-d75f-11eb-843b-205021b50273.png)

- How about omitting the cache name in the title bar...most of the time it does not fit anyway and its now already contained in the content below?
- The cache icon looks a bit narrow compared to the buttons on the right hand side. Does it have the same width/height already?
- What could we show instead of the title? Nothing or something like "Cache info" (if it fits in all languages)?
- It also looks strange, that the height of "More Details" (outline) is more narrow than the outline of the icon next to it.

Other thought:
Would a bottom sheet maybe suitable to replace it completely?
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/949669/123547222-37ec5700-d760-11eb-8280-58af09e0e4f2.png)

After clicking on a cache it could show its name only (one liner as in the example above) and the user can expand it to view the other details... Just thinking...no idea if its suitable and according to the meant usage of this element.

title: Image select activity: Refactor buttons
body:
## What function are you missing
In the "add image" activity (which is part of the logging activity) you get three buttons on editing an uploaded image: cancel / ok / delete (in this order).

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3754370/122640123-fde6d980-d0fd-11eb-92b8-c0c19fd5341e.png)


IMHO this should be refactored, as
- text gets truncated (although they are relatively short)
- "ok" button should be the right-most button

## Suggested solution
I have no perfect solution at hand, but I guess confusion stems from the fact that we are trying to do two different things in one dialog:
- edit a description (which needs "cancel" and "ok")
- offer to delete an attached image

Maybe the solution would be to remove the "delete" button. You can still delete the image from the list of images.

title: Show full cache name in cache preview
body: There are many geocache series out there that use the following name schema: ``` A very very very long description prefix #1 A very very very long description prefix #2 ... ``` **When clicking a cache on the map in cgeo only the first part of the name is displayed - often not containing the important information at the end.** It would be nice to immediately see the full name without having to additionally clicking on details. If there is no cell phone reception, showing the details might not even work! Rotating the screen is a workaround, but very annoying and the name might be still too long. IMHO smartphone displays should be large enough nowadays to show the full name. Maybe make it multi line text and/or adjust the text size. Example ([GC97DZB](https://www.geocaching.com/geocache/GC97DZB)): The full cache name/number `Traumrunde Prichsenstadt #04` is only visible after rotating the device.

title: Deactivate image buttons "extract waypoints to PN" and "delete extractred waypoints from PN" when they are not useful
body:
**Describe the bug:**
Recent c:geo introduced several new features. 
One can be seen in the cache screen, below the description.

**To Reproduce:**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. open a cache
2. go to description screen, scroll down
3. under "personal note" you will see 3 buttons. always.
![btn-4](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3382777/103480960-76700d00-4de0-11eb-9f3c-01f1bf0c10b0.png)

**Actual behavior/state after performing these steps:**
4. try to press the indicated button. **Nothing happens.**

**Expected behavior/state after performing these steps:**
From the icon I deduce it might have something to do with some waypoints. Being in this section would mean some waypoints of a different nature then the usual waypoints available on their dedicated screen. 
The trashcan icon in the upper right suggest to me that this button is meant to delete something. 
I presume there would be situations when under Personal note you could see some waypoints. And this button was meant to delete some/all of those waypoints. 

However, since there are no waypoints, there is nothing to delete. 
IMO this button should be shown only when there actually is content for it to act upon.

**Version of c:geo used:**
2020.12.03

**Is the problem reproducible:**
Yes

title: Installation wizard
body:
While browsing through the Play Store review notifications I've stumbled upon a wide spread between recurring users (beta reviews) and other users (regular reviews). While most beta reviews are four or five star reviews, other reviews have a high occurence of one star reviews, frequently with remarks like
- no caches shown
- no search does work
- app does not work
- Did not let me see ANY geocaches only let me see the map
- ...

IMHO there is a problem with onboarding our new users, the learning curve for c:geo is too steep.

A couple of days ago, while working on a different issue, I had to install a new app "Lockito" for automatically looping over a self-created track. I had no idea how this app worked, but after installation a short wizard took me through the most relevant settings, and so I had this app up and running in no time.

That's when my old idea of a tiny installation wizard for c:geo resurfaced. Today I started working on it, and have come up with the following so far:
|![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3754370/103156498-65544a00-47a9-11eb-9618-134388b362fd.png)|![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3754370/103156501-6ab19480-47a9-11eb-9e38-99e84dd40000.png)|
|![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3754370/103156504-6eddb200-47a9-11eb-9f3e-b61393443bd1.png)|![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3754370/103156508-7309cf80-47a9-11eb-9d20-17730ac60e5c.png)|
|![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3754370/103156512-7735ed00-47a9-11eb-94a2-ac0cd9633d29.png)|![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3754370/103156515-7c933780-47a9-11eb-99d6-131706367871.png)|
|![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3754370/103156517-8157eb80-47a9-11eb-9a70-b655f6bd4243.png)|![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3754370/103156519-85840900-47a9-11eb-8130-bef2ab590a9b.png)|
|![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3754370/103156521-8a48bd00-47a9-11eb-9796-7684192242cf.png)||

As a "bonus" you can select "advanced" on the last screen for an easy access to some more advanced settings:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3754370/103156524-8fa60780-47a9-11eb-97db-c1cc2cb6dd60.png)

This, BTW, also makes our BRouter integration a bit more prominent, as has been mentioned (wished for) earlier in some other issue.

title: Add option to convert all variable names to lower case in WP calc editor
body:
I've been doing a couple of Multis throughout the last week, using the WP calculator from stage to stage. Doing so, I frequently stumbled upon the problem, that most formulas in listings use upper case letters, whereas the waypoint calculator expects lower case letters.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Add a button to replace upper-case letters in the left part of the calculator (`*`) by their lower-case equivalents. This would be a one-time operation, so on each press of this button the variables in (`*`) would be lower-cased, but you would still be able to enter upper-case letters after that without them being lower-cased automatically.

(`*`) meaning the marked box in this screenshot:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3754370/96377770-0ca07980-1188-11eb-8531-ec4f52584d64.png)

The button could be named "lower-case formula contents" or simply "lower-case" and being placed within the red box, but below the formulas.

title: [Nightly] Improve explanation text of "FoundCount +x" popup
body:
Topic deals with the popup, which appears after the first start of c:geo after upgrading to the version which contains the "+x" behind the cache found count in the footer of c:geo's main screen: 

![Popup](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9889015/93458381-840c9000-f8e0-11ea-9279-f4607a396a27.jpg)

When I saw this popup the very first time, I thought it could be hard to understand esp. for somebody who never ever had seen the "+" before or even has paid attention to this counter at all. So I would be a bit more descriptive like:

```
You have some caches with an offline saved log,
which are not yet uploaded to geocaching,com.
For your comfort the count of these logs is now
displayed as "+x" behind your number of found
caches in the footer at c:geo's main page.

Moreover these "x" logs will be added to the
"[NUMBER]" template in your log signature.

If you don't like this new counter extension,
you can disable it under "Settings" => "Logging"
and/or use the "[NUMBER (without offline logs)"
template instead.

To easily find remaining offline logs, go to the
list "History" and filter for "With personal data
 => "With offline log".

[_] Don't show this message again     [OK]
```

As most of the users will not know what this will mean, I would add the ``Don't shown again`` marker.
This way they have the chance to see the counter at least once and then read again.

title: Ease onboarding with offline maps, part 2
body:
This is part two to ease onboarding with offline maps for new users of c:geo, in addition (or as partial replacement) of #8180/#8183:

- add a link to the map selector: "Download offline maps"
- which opens a directory listing of the Mapsforge server (actually its mirror at fh-esslingen.de)
- You can browse through the directories up and down and select a file (map) to download.
- Map file gets downloaded in the background using Android's download manager.
- On completion the map file gets copied into c:geo map directory and activated as current map. (as in #8183).

This is how it looks like:

New menu entry "Download offline map" in map selection menu:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3754370/87226999-05531e00-c398-11ea-9d42-85145273d8b3.png)
(the thin separator line is available on Android 10+ only)

Retrieved the initial listing of the v5 map directory:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3754370/87227020-26b40a00-c398-11ea-9ec2-e234ba27754c.png)

Retrieving a sub directory, "Australia-Oceania" in this case:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3754370/87227029-39c6da00-c398-11ea-829b-9ca4bfc50327.png)

For downloadable map files size and date of last change are shown:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3754370/87227043-4cd9aa00-c398-11ea-86d0-2c00b121423f.png)

When you select a map for downloading, you get a short notification that the download starts in the background. You can continue to work with c:geo until the download has finished:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3754370/87227066-6c70d280-c398-11ea-9ad5-68d65904680c.png)

When the download has finished the file gets copied to c:geo map dir automatically:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3754370/87227074-83afc000-c398-11ea-8080-44cea75b8ea3.png)

Finally you get a confirmation that the download has succeeded:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3754370/87227079-96c29000-c398-11ea-9017-c679019f186c.png)
The newly downloaded map gets activated as current map automatically.

---

Current state of this PR is beta. Next steps are:
- creating and merging the "extension table" PR, which is a prerequisite
- a bit of minor roundup on this, then creating "map download" PR
- testing, testing, testing, ...

Any feedback is very welcome.

title: make onboarding with offline maps easier for new users of c:geo
body:
One of the steepest hurdles for new users of c:geo is installing an offline map, IMHO. Thus probably most new users (except technically very savant) stick to Google maps and miss one of the greatest features of c:geo - offline caching.

There have been proposals for downloading maps in the past (eg #6072, #7529), but they are very sophisticated approaches which try to automate everything and cover a wide range of use cases. Sadly, they are also a bit more heavy to implement, not only on our side but on providers' side as well, and nobody has done it yet.

I propose a more basic approach with the focus on simplifying onboarding for new users of c:geo:
- Skip themeing, only support downloading map files for this onboarding feature. Therefore use a map source which does not need a separate theme file. (This would be the hs-esslingen mirror of download.mapsforge.org)
- Direct the user to the relevant directory, let them download the map file using the browser, and make c:geo integrate the downloaded file...
- ... which would include copying the file to c:geo map directory, set the map provider and current map file accordingly.

Implementation wise there are three areas of work:
- [x] Offer a link to the map download site
- [x] Recognize downloaded map files and move them to c:geo maps dir (current map dir, if already set, or new default one)
- [x] Set map handler and current map file accordingly

I've started working on it. Current state is:

a) Initiate download via Settings => Map => Download basic offline maps:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3754370/78711262-fbdc9480-7916-11ea-8c0c-d571932ed6f6.png)

b) Info screen:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3754370/78711297-0a2ab080-7917-11ea-93c9-fc4f9bb403d9.png)

c) Detecting that a map already exists under the same file name:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3754370/79076617-c90e1400-7cfb-11ea-8337-44032687df2a.png)

d) cancellable progress dialog during transfer:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3754370/79076626-e642e280-7cfb-11ea-8df3-d7f4233deaa7.png)


e) confirmation dialog after successful installation:
(recognition of file name depends on Android version and map source; may be a more generic name like "5.map" or "msf:27.map")
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3754370/78916095-41bb6900-7a8d-11ea-8539-4db4a0731a2f.png)

Alternatively you can tap on a map file stored locally. This would enter the process shown above at step c).

This is work in progress. May be ready featurewise, but needs more testing with other file types (locally and online) as well as under more Android versions.

title: Implement "Result Highlighting" in the Calculator.
body:
As mentioned in #6716 (Managing ambiguous results in WP Calc where trailing/leading zeros are involved) it can be necessary to insert additional zeros into the result of a formulation, and in some instances there is contention as to whether these should be 'leading-zeros' or 'trailing-zeros'.  It has been suggested that a method of identifying how a result has been manipulated would be desirable and a suggestion made is to colour the 'manipulated' digits differently to provide this indication:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6573522/32086853-90e4e82e-bb1f-11e7-95aa-de13c587272f.png)

Developer notes:
>Implementing this is not as trivial as one might at first think for a few reasons:
>
>The main concern is that the text to display for a valid location is actually obtained from the waypoint itself rather than from the input strings used to create it.  This is done specifically so that users can be aware of exactly what the resulting waypoint will actually represent rather than their entered value (which may result in something they did not expect).  Although we have access to both the input string and the resulting GeoPoint's string displaying a 'diff' of these two strings is not as trivial as you may think.
>
>However, once it is known what colours should be used for each letter actually displaying the desired results shouldn't be too hard given TextView's support the use of HTML strings.

Further notes:
>Once implemented this "Syntax Highlighting" would be most useful in conveying information to users of what leads to "Parsing Failures" (as related to #6802: Coordinate Parser Needs Work).
